titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Pavel Tchelitchew Collection
titlestmt.author: by Lisa Conathan

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 03:58

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The collection includes correspondence, writings, photographs and printed material that document the life and work of Russian-born painter and set designer Pavel Tchelitchew. Correspondence includes letters between Tchelitchew and Edith Sitwell. Writings include the memoir of Tchelitchew's sister Alexandra Zaousailloff.

langmaterial.language: In Russian, English,French and other languages.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The collection contains material of mixed provenance acquired by purchase and donation from various sources.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

Restricted Fragile in box 30 may be consulted only with permission of the appropriate curator. Preservation photocopies or photographic prints for reference use have been substituted in the main files.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Pavel Tchelitchew Collection is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Pavel Tchelitchew Collection. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Formerly partially processed under the call numbers ZA Tchelitchew and GEN MSS 466. Processing completed and finding aid revised in 2009.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Correspondence with Edith Sitwell is available on microfilm.

bioghist.head: Pavel Tchelitchew, 1898-1957
bioghist.p: Russian-born painter, set designer, and costume designer, Pavel Tchelitchew emigrated in 1920. He lived in Berlin (1921-23) and Paris (1923-34) before moving to New York, where he lived with his partner Charles Henri Ford. He became a United States citizen in 1952 and died in Grottaferrata, Italy in 1957.

Tchelitchew's early painting was abstract in style, described as Constructivist and Futurist and influenced by his study with Aleksandra Ekster in Kiev. After emigrating to Paris he became associated with the Neoromanticism movement. He continuously experimented with new styles, eventually incorporating multiple perspectives and elements of surrealism and fantasy into his painting. As a set and costume designer, he collaborated with Serge Diaghliev and George Balanchine, among others.

In Paris Tchelitchew became acquainted with Gertrude Stein and, through her, the Sitwell and Gorer families. He and Edith Sitwell had a long-standing close friendship and they corresponded frequently.

Among Tchelitchew's well-known paintings are portraits of Natalia Glasko, Edith Sitwell and Gertrude Stein and the works Phenomena (1936-1938) and Cache Cache (1940-1942). He designed sets for Ode (Paris, 1928), L'Errante (Paris, 1933), Nobilissima Visione (London, 1938) and Ondine (Paris, 1939), among other productions.

bioghist.head: Alexandra Zaoussailoff
bioghist.p: Alexandra Zaoussailoff was sister of Pavel Tchelitchew; he addressed her as Choura (in Russian: Shura). She was the only other member of Tchelitchew's immediate family to emigrate from Russia and lived primarily in Paris.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of correspondence, writings, photographs, and printed material that document the artistic pursuits and personal life of Russian-born painter, set designer, and costume designer Pavel Tchelitchew. The material documents Tchelitchew's assessment of his own work, the conception and execution of many of his paintings and his business dealings with collectors, galleries and museums. In addition to documentation of Tchelitchew's life as an emigre, some material relates to his early life in Russia. A memoir of Tchelitchew's sister Alexandra Zaoussailoff (unpublished during her lifetime) recounts their childhood and describes their family background and upbringing. A few official documents attest to Tchelitchew's noble ancestry and his early education.

Most of the correspondence in the collection is with close friends and family, documenting both personal relationships and business activity. A portion of the correspondence relates specifically to Tchelitchew's business dealings with collectors, museums and galleries. Among the writings are short autobiographical sketches and self-reflective essays examining his development as an artist. The printed material includes collected images from magazines, postcards or books that he saved for their influence on his work. Photographs date chiefly from the years prior to the Second World War, when Tchelitchew, Zaoussailoff and friends spent their summers in Guermantes, France.

In addition to the primary research interest of Tchelitchew's life and work, the collection documents several aspects of twentieth century art and history. Tchelitchew's correspondence documents the cosmopolitan nature of artistic society before and after the Second World War in Europe and the United States. Family correspondence throughout the collection and Zaoussailoff's memoir document the social history of a post-Revolutionary aristocratic Russian family.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into four series: I. Correspondence, 1923-1957. II Writings, 1934-1951. III. Printed Material, 1916-1971. IV Photographs and Other Papers, 1907-1970.

odd.head: Appendix: Guide to the Microfilm
odd.p: Series I, correspondence between Pavel Tchelitchew and Edith Sitwell and other papers found with Sitwell-Tchelitchew correspondence are available on microfilm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Pavel Tchelitchew Correspondence documents Tchelitchew's artistic and personal life and the business of selling, lending and exhibiting his paintings. It includes six boxes of letters to and from Edith Sitwell, documenting their close friendship and professional collaboration. Tchelitchew discusses his artistic projects, creative inspiration and the practicalities of showing and selling his paintings. Sitwell discusses her many writings and some letters include drafts of her poems.

The correspondence also includes family letters, which provide a glimpse of the daily life of an aristrocratic family in the early Soviet era and include discussion of the family's difficult financal situation. Correspondence with his sister Alexandra documents their lives as emigres in Europe and the United States and their collaboration on matters related to Tchelitchew's career.

Alexandra Zaousailloff Correspondence is with family members and friends and associates of Pavel Tchelitchew. Family correspondence relates news about the lives of sisters Varvara Zarudnaia and Mariia Klimenko in Russia; correspondence with others relates chiefly to matters related to Tchelitchew's career and to Zaousailloff's memoir.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Correspondence is organized under two headings: Pavel Tchelitchew Correspondence and Alexandra Zaoussailoff Correspondence. Arranged alphabetically under each heading.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Correspondence identified by first name only, unsorted general correspondence and unsorted business papers and correspondence are filed at the end of the alphabetical listing.

scopecontent.p: Letters are incoming unless otherwise specified.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Letters are unsorted within the folders.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Business correspondence and papers document Tchelitchew's exhibitions and the sale of his works. The papers include notes and lists of paintings detailing dimensions and titles. Also included are immigration documents, medical records and financial records. Official documents are also filed in Series IV.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Letters and papers are unsorted within the folders.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Incoming unless otherwise indicated.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes excerpts translated into English by Lamont Moore.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Microfilm available of one undated letter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes notes on his art by Pavel Tchelitchew, a lecture by Tchelitchew, Alexandra Zaousailloff's memoir, and writings of others about Tchelitchew. Also includes a script of Ondine by Jean Giraudoux, for which Tchelitchew designed the set in 1939. Tchelitchew's notes on his art were likely written to aid in the preparation of exhibit catalogs or other material on Tchelitchew. Zaousailloff's memoir recounts the life of the Chelishchev family in Russia until the time of Pavel Tchelitchew's emigration (circa 1898-1920). Included here are drafts of French and English translations of the memoir; the Russian-language original is not part of the collection.
All writings are typescript drafts unless otherwise indicated.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Zaoussailoff's memoir exists in several versions. It was presumably written in Russian, though the Russian-language version is not in the collection. Parker Tyler and Allen Tanner used a French translation as a source for their English translations. The collection contains no record of a printed verison of the memoir.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged roughly by type of material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Printed material includes catalogs and announcements related to the exhibition and sale of Tchelitchew's paintings, material that Tchelitchew collected as inspiration ("Influences"), newspaper clippings about Tchelitchew and serial publications about art and theater from the early twentieth century, some of which contain material about Tchelitchew. Also includes programs for theater and ballet performances, for many of which Tchelitchew designed costumes or sets.

scopecontent.p: Includes photographs, official documents, diaries, engagement books, two sketches by Tchelitchew and one audio recording of a speech by Tchelitchew.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographs are snapshots taken in Guermantes, France and include acquaintances who visited Tchelitchew there.
Photographs also include portraits, most stored in Oversize, of Tchelitchew, Edith Sitwell, Charles Henri Ford and others, photographed by Cecil Beaton and George Platt Lynes.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Restricted fragile material. Reference surrogates have been substituted in the main files. For further information consult the appropriate curator.
